oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ku Klux Klan (1915- ); Simmons, W. J. (William Joseph), 1880-1945
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front cover of the pamphlet, "A, B, C of the Invisble Empire, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan." It features a central image of a hooded Klan member above the words, "Faultless, Fearless, and Forever Faithful," and the dates, "1866 - Founded" and "1915 - Incorporated." It asks for "an urgent call to real men" from Imperial Wizard Col. W. J. Simmons.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Colonel W. J. Simmons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The pamphlet was produced in 1915 after the Ku Klux Klan was reborn in a surge of pro-Klan excitement stemming from D. W. Griffith's romanticized portrayal of the 1866 Klan in "Birth of a Nation" and the lynching of a Jewish factory owner, Leo Frank, in Atlanta. The influx of new immigrants broadened the scope of the Klan's focus far beyond that of the 1866 Klan. Publisher Thomas E. Watson and W. J. Simmons called the first meeting of the new Klan at Stone Mountain, Georgia, in 1915.
